DOC.brief_summary: Esophagectomy for cancer is often accompanied with severe preoperative weight loss. Body Mass Index (BMI) values are age-independent and the same for both sexes. From the perspective that these two parameters should actually be taken into account too, we developed a model to calculate "age-gender specific BMI-percentiles" (AG-BMI) and tested this model in relation to survival outcome after esophagectomy for cancer.
DOC.brief_title: Age and Gender Corrected Body Mass Index
DOC.detailed_description: Age-Gender specific BMI percentiles are more accurate compared to the current BMI classes in predicting Overall Survival (OS) after esophagectomy for cancer. Furthermore we believe in a more devastating impact on OS from underweight and not from overweight. By preoperatively identifying risk patients for poorer OS, especially the non-tumoral deaths, this can be a tool to tailor postoperative nutritional strategies to counter further weight loss and bringing postoperative weight to normal ranges.
DOC.criteria: any type of esophagectomy Preoperative organ metastasis (cM+ or yM+) esophageal bypass surgery
